newsitem.title: SLOVENIA: Bank SKB surges 22 pct on wave of buying.
newsitem.headline: Bank SKB surges 22 pct on wave of buying.

text.p: Feverish demand and reluctant sellers combined to power Slovenian bank SKB more than 21 percent higher on Tuesday after the Ljubljana bourse decided to lift its daily 10 percent limit on moves.

By 1003 GMT, SKB was up at 60,000 tolars from its January 20 close of 49,300. The bourse reinstated trading of the shares after a one-week suspension pending an announcement from SKB over recent sharp price gains.
The bourse decided to lift its daily limit of 10 percent since no investors had been prepared to sell at the early morning bid of 55,000 tolars.
Traders said SKB may well surge over 30 percent now that the limit had been removed.
"If the bourse lifts the limit the price could well go up to 70,000 or 75,000," Danilo Grasic, head of investment at Creditanstalt said earlier.

Demand for SKB soared due to the bank's plan to list global depository receipts on the London stock exchange by mid-February -- approved by the Bank of Slovenia last week. -- Ljubljana newsroom, 386-61-125-8439
